keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen is approaching the Philippine island of Catanduanes, prompting thousands of residents to evacuate due to predicted coastal flooding and high winds.
The storm is expected to bring heavy rainfall and waves up to 1.2 meters, posing a minimal to moderate risk of coastal flooding.
More than 9,000 residents from Catanduanes have relocated to safer areas, reflecting a repeated and proactive evacuation drill due to the islandâ€™s frequent exposure to cyclones.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, with climate change increasing storm intensity due to global warming.
The country is still recovering from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons in recent weeks, which have resulted in significant loss of life and infrastructure damage.
Typhoon Ragasa in late September and a magnitude 6.9 and 7.4 earthquake earlier in the month illustrate the recurring and escalating nature of natural disasters in the region.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents in the Philippine island of Catanduanes have evacuated their homes ahead of Tropical Storm Fengshen, which is expected to pass near the island with strong winds and a moderate risk of coastal flooding from 1.2-meter waves. This evacuation is part of a recurring drill, as Catanduanes is often the first landmass affected by cyclones from the western Pacific. The Philippines, already reeling from a series of earthquakes and typhoons in recent weeks, faces heightened climate-related risks due to global warming, with scientists warning of increasingly powerful storms. The storm comes amid a pattern of disaster events, including Typhoon Ragasa and major earthquakes in Cebu and southern regions, illustrating the country's ongoing struggle with natural hazards and disaster recovery.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
